Ron Shalit
Apr 12

Does A Chatbot Need NLP To¬†Succeed?

Like every good response to a deep philosophical question, the answer to this one starts with ‚Äúit depends‚Ä¶‚Äù

I would say that the success of a chatbot can be defined as its ability to provide a superior user experience in comparison to alternative interaction models, like apps and websites. If all your chatbot is trying to do is help a user navigate through limited scope options, you may be able to successfully come up with all possible responses for every junction in the conversation and just let the user pick one at a time to move the conversation forward.

A good example is a bot that only let its users subscribe to periodical content updates. Select the desired frequency‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääand you‚Äôre done. The rest of the ‚Äúconversation‚Äù is just the updates that the bot sends.

This approach is far from being scalable, though. Even moderately complex conversations would quickly become cumbersome and long-winded. Adding questions or modifying the flow would require re-thinking the entire conversation model, quickly becoming a maintenance and QA nightmare.

An NLP-based model, when works well, opens up the opportunity to solve highly complex problems and answer complicated questions with a simple interface that every human can understand immediately. This is not to say that such open-ended chatbots should refrain from using pre-built responses as an option, as these can provide useful shortcuts to tireless typing.

With that said, those of us that have been working on NLP for a while know that not all NLP models are alike. As the latest stats from chatbots running of Facebook shows, the success rate of chatbots in understanding humans is rather dismal at this point.

As humans, we are not only listening to what another person is telling us, we also use context to understand the intent behind the words. A good chatbot need more than just NLP, it needs a good understanding of context and intent. In addition to advanced Natural Language Understanding, a good chatbot would also have extensive domain-specific capabilities embedded into the conversation models.

In our tests, we have found that adding context to the Natural Language Understanding (NLU) model‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääin our case the context is derived based on financial transaction data‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääcan catapult the level of understanding up to 90%, which is leaps and bounds higher than other NLP systems.

For example, when a customer asks about overdraft options, our chatbot is able to interpret the question in the context of the person‚Äôs account status at that moment, such as current funds available and whether overdraft protection is in place. Using predictive analytics capabilities, it would even consider whether the account is expected to be overdrawn in the coming weeks and tailor the response accordingly.

So, does a chatbot need NLP to succeed? In some cases, you can get by without NLP. However, for chatbots to be helpful in conducting complex business conversations, NLP alone would not suffice either‚Ää‚Äî‚Ääyou need a good NLU model with domain-specific knowledge that can understand and embed context into the conversation.

Ron is the Director of Product Innovation at Personetics. Before joining Personetics, Ron has accrued more than 10 years of experience in various positions between software development and product management.
